turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about V'Zot HaBerachah.
turn.2: V'Zot HaBerachah V'Zot HaBerachah, VeZos HaBerachah, VeZot Haberakha, V'Zeis Habrocho, V'Zaus Haberocho, V'Zois Haberuchu, or Zos Habrocho ( – Hebrew for "and this is the blessing," the first words in the parashah) is the 54th and final weekly Torah portion (, "parashah") in the annual Jewish cycle of Torah reading and the 11th and last in the Book of Deuteronomy.
turn.6: The parashah sets out the farewell Blessing of Moses for the 12 Tribes of Israel and concludes with the death of Moses.
turn.8: It is made up of 1,969 Hebrew letters, 512 Hebrew words, and 41 verses.
turn.9: Is there anything else notable about this passage?
turn.10: The parashah has the fewest letters and words, (Parashah Vayelech, with just 30 verses, has fewer verses), of any of the 54 weekly Torah portions.
turn.12: Jews generally read it in September or October on the Simchat Torah festival.
